statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

article.description: The Sonics set a team record by shooting over 66 percent and, behind Gary Payton's 28 points, beat the Philadelphia 76ers 109-98 Monday.
article.headline: Sonics' 66-percent shooting dazzling

images.name: Payton_Gary 012102 inline
images.caption: Gary Payton had 28 points and 11 assists to lead the Sonics.

article.linkText: Hot Sonics set club shooting record in Philly
article.story:
PHILADELPHIA (AP) -- The Seattle SuperSonics couldn't miss. At least it seemed that way. The Sonics set a team record by shooting over 66 percent and, behind Gary Payton's 28 points, beat the Philadelphia 76ers 109-98 Monday. "We were in a rhythm with everybody shooting the ball well," Payton said. Allen Iverson led the Sixers with 38 points, and became the eighth player in Philadelphia history to score 10,000 career points. The Sonics shot 41-of-62 (66.1 percent) in ending the Sixers' four-game winning streak. Seattle's previous best was 64.9 percent against Houston on April 13, 1996. "The first time we played them (an 87-77 loss on Jan. 4), we couldn't make a bucket. Today we did a good job of executing and concentrated on making our shots," Payton said. Payton, who made 10-of-16 shots, scored 10 points in the decisive third quarter. He also handed out 11 assists. Vin Baker added 20 points for the Sonics, who had five players in double figures. "We definitely shot the ball well today," Sonics coach Nate McMillan said. "We did a good job of executing our offense, setting screens and moving the ball to the open shooter." Seattle dominated the third quarter, shooting 14-for-17 and outscoring the Sixers 36-20 to take an 85-65 lead. Payton shot 4-for-4 in the period. "We couldn't guard them the whole game," Sixers coach Larry Brown said. "We didn't handle their pick-and-roll or dribble penetration and we didn't talk a few times. You name it, we got exposed. It's disappointing." Dikembe Mutombo and Matt Harpring each had 13 points for Philadelphia. Payton's three-point play increased Seattle's advantage to 73-60 with 4:20 left in the third quarter. After Iverson made a jumper, the Sonics closed the quarter with a 12-3 run. Rashard Lewis had nine points in the period, and finished with 17 for the Sonics. Iverson went over 10,000 career points with a 3-pointer from the right wing with 8:50 left in the game. "I give a lot of credit to myself, but also to my teammates, coach Brown and the coaching staff," Iverson said. Seattle, which averages 14.4 turnovers per game, made 12 in the first half. But the Sonics made 21-of-33 shots and took a 49-45 lead at halftime on Lewis' 3-pointer at the buzzer.

Game notes
Seattle set a First Union Center record for field goal shooting, eclipsing the 64.2 percent by Minnesota on Jan. 9, 2000. ... Sixers forward Derrick Coleman missed his third straight game with left foot inflammation. ... Seattle is 19-1 when scoring more than 100 points. ... Eagles wide receiver Freddie Mitchell was in attendance. He got a standing ovation when he was introduced to the crowd with 8:38 left.
